body: I'm doing it on #2032. I'll merge that if it's better.
ok just looked at the other PR, I think merging is good idea so that you can use the method from here for real and it will be clearer.

`descending` would be about the order of processing, not about ordering of result. So it can be applied to all kind of queries but whether it has any meaning is a different question. 

For example, descending processing of time-series queries will make descending ordered result(good). But for group-by queries, the order of processing has no meaning and there are another ordering spec for result ordering in it. For search queries? because druid just lookups index and dictionary, it just not have meaning of order of processing.

I think time-series and search queries can make differences by this. But for others, I don't know.
can you also add a test to GroupByQueryRunnerTest, just to make sure the entire groupBy query works as expected ?
+1, I am in after squashing commits.

can we clean unused imports in a separate PR ? 
Its good to separate unrelated things in separate PR's helps in backporting things to different branches.
Looks good to me.

For sanity sake, can you test that when two configs which omit the unique ID are created via json deserialization, that they have different IDs?
If this needs to be in fast I'm ok without it, but it would be nice to have an actual "is it unique" test
@himanshug addressed comment
@b-slim  The performance gain from:(1)As less as new Text(String) which will encode String to UTF-8 (2)Write dimension name only once.

@drcrallen added test for assigned id's being unique. 
regarding "is it unique" test, given that path has timestamp and uuid in it, IMO it will be fine.

Hey @gianm! I just filled the form :)

you're welcome :)

Standalone RealtimeNode fails to start with Guice provision errors -

```
1) Error injecting constructor, java.lang.RuntimeException: com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.JsonMappingException: Guice configuration errors:

1) No implementation for io.druid.segment.realtime.plumber.SegmentHandoffNotifier was bound.
  while locating io.druid.segment.realtime.plumber.SegmentHandoffNotifier

1 error (through reference chain: java.util.ArrayList[0])
  at io.druid.guice.FireDepartmentsProvider.<init>(FireDepartmentsProvider.java:41)
  while locating io.druid.guice.FireDepartmentsProvider
  at io.druid.guice.RealtimeModule.configure(RealtimeModule.java:88)
  while locating java.util.List<io.druid.segment.realtime.FireDepartment>
    for parameter 0 at io.druid.segment.realtime.RealtimeManager.<init>(RealtimeManager.java:80)
  while locating io.druid.segment.realtime.RealtimeManager
  at io.druid.guice.RealtimeModule.configure(RealtimeModule.java:102)
  while locating io.druid.query.QuerySegmentWalker
    for parameter 3 at io.druid.server.QueryResource.<init>(QueryResource.java:90)
  while locating io.druid.server.QueryResource
```

I guess the problem is that in case of standalone node, `RealtimePlumberSchool` object is directly initialized by Guice when `FireDepartment` object is created and it is expecting binding for `SegmentHandoffNotifier`
@guobingkun I closed your PR to restart the build but not able to Reopen it due to a force push. can you please create another PR? thanks.
@pjain1 thanks for checking it out, looking into it.
@jukukl Could you please fill out the CLA at http://druid.io/community/cla.html ? and squash your commits.
@himanshug reopened as #2056.
Adding a testcase to GroupByQueryRunnerTest is nice to have but I feel not needed for this change.
@pjain1: the realtime node got broken when i refactored things during handling review comments, fixed now.
Other than storing the reference in an AtomicReference, I'm :+1:
@himanshug Done.
@kzarzycki your topN query includes an "or" filter. Please remove it.
@kzarzycki Please see "Counting the number of ingested events" here: http://druid.io/docs/latest/ingestion/schema-design.html
@kzarzycki also, your topN query's "intervals" field doesn't match your raw data
I think this bug is fixed by #1632.
Minor comments but :+1:. This is a really useful feature IMO
What is the use case that the PR is solving? I'm wondering because for some of this information this PR appears to be addressing, why not use the segment metadata query to retrieve it?
:+1:, minor comment: can we document what the default names and ports are somewhere? E.g. common configuration?
@fjy This is used in the Broker endpoint /druid/v2/datasources/{dataSourceName}, specifically in the ClientInfoResource.java
@guobingkun I understand, my thought is more if we shoudl think about deprecating that endpoint in favor of segment metadata, which is what all the UIs out there use right now
@cheddar @guobingkun wouldn't it make sense to fix realtime announcement instead? Since segments are immutable, there shouldn't be a reason for the broker to update that information, is there?
@xvrl the "dimensions" field cannot really be immutable in realtime due to schemaless dimension discovery-- more might show up over time as the segment gets built.

Aside from wanting to add the bulk methods as well, I'm :+1: on this.  The primary change is the `LookupExtractor` and then there's a bunch of changes to the only known current extension.

I agree with separating the cleaning of imports.  We should either do that in its own PR or opportunistically as those classes are touched.

For this PR, I could see an argument for adding the usages of the new interface method as well.  I.e. the broker's optimizations that can be enabled by this.  I can also see an argument for doing that in its own PR.  I'm ok with either of them.
Looks great, thanks!

@fjy I thought the current implementation of segmentMetaQuery is slow for looking up metadata because it has to scan actual columns? I agree with you that we should deprecate this endpoint in favor of improved segmentMetadata query in the near future. I think this fix is needed for now, and probably also fine in the future.

@fjy updated.

Is it ok to merge into master?
I'm cool but need another +1
Current name of this metric is **task/run/time**, and it is already fixed.
We can probably close right? #2017 is merged
Fixed by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2017

@gianm an alternative would be for realtime nodes to announce a new segment version for handoff. This way metadata would never have to change and there would be a clear distinction between a segment that doesn't change (as is the case for handoff) and a segment that is still evolving its schema. The understanding would then be that any change in metadata also requires a new segment version.

@xvrl that's gonna make handoff not work properly- the higher version post-handoff would cause the other partitions for the same interval to be shadowed.

Also the segment metadata does change as part of handoff even without thinking about dimensions; it only gains a "size" and "loadSpec" after it is pushed.
@guobingkun the behavior to scan columns is now optional I thought, see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1753

This seems handy but I want to make sure I understand what its trying to communicate. It currently only evaluates if a result has ANY data within an interval, regardless of the completeness of the data.

I suppose I'm not quite sure what the intended problem to solve here is. If it is simply that perhaps there is a hole in the data, then I can understand this does communicate "the data in the query is supposed to be indexed and loaded"

But if it is trying to communicate the completeness of the data, it is not immediately obvious if that is covered by this. For example, if a historical node is in the process of loading a date range(say a rolling restart with no replication), but it is no _all_ available, then this would return that the interval is present, when in fact it might not be "complete".

Could you expand a little more (and put in a code comment) what this is supposed to communicate?
I'm :+1: once its documented exactly what its supposed to communicate, and the verbiage of the copyright notice is verified

When you issue a query to a broker, you say, "give me results for this time range".  When the broker looks to the segments that exist on the server, sometimes it won't actually have a complete set of segments for the entire time range specified.  This will populate the "uncoveredIntervals" that did not have a segment loaded.

I do not believe there are any races with historicals reloading or anything like that.  The broker rewrites its queries into per-segment specifiers before sending to historicals, so if the broker is unaware of the segment, the result won't include results from that segment.

@cheddar if a query interval is used which extends beyond the scope of data (example: "`1970-01-01T00:00:00Z/3000-01-01T00:00:00Z`"), then I think this would return pretty well what a user would expect.

But if an interval is well within the scope of the data, then this should only return intervals which definitely have "missing" data. which is a different statement than "should have all data". So I was just hoping you could clarify as a comment that this is not intended as an indicator that all data in the interval is fully loaded.

@drcrallen It is telling you which intervals were covered by segments and which were not.  That seems very succinct and technically accurate.  I'm not understanding what distinction you are trying to draw, perhaps provide a counter proposal for a comment in the code (I'm guessing that's what you are wanting?)

Proposed code comment:

`// Only returns intervals for which NO data is present. Should not be used to guarantee completeness of returned data`
@cheddar one more comment to please add some docs on how this can be used.
@fjy do we already have response headers documented somewhere in the docs, or will a new section need to be created?

@cheddar Hmmm, they are not documented. We need a query response page similar to query context.

It might make sense to follow up those docs in another PR

@fjy do you want to deprecate that end point in this PR or separate one? I think the fix in this PR is actually not related to deprecation since ServerSelector exposes getSegment(), and it makes sense for  ServerSelector to return the segment that has the final state of metadata.
@fjy agree with separate PR for docs since they don't exist yet
Cool, thanks. :+1:  after travis
:+1: Thanks for this catch
After reading https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1984 I am :+1: on this. Please squash commits.
@gianm @pjain1 any more comments here?

@binlijin @himanshug does this mean that the InputRowSerde introduced in #1472 caused performance degradation? How does this new ser/de compare to just passing Text between mapper and reducer (ignoring the combiner for a moment)?

@navis this is a tricky one, there are lots of thorny Guava issues when running on hadoop, which ships an old version of guava. This means we cannot use anything beyond what is available in Guava 11 for any code that could be executed during hadoop indexing.
@xvrl is correct, do you happen to have the guava version these things were added in?

@xvrl this is used in batch ingestion only . batch ingestion runtime is mostly dependent upon actual indexing and trips of data to/from hdfs, serding time here plays little role . We did not notice any significant differences in our batch ingestion times post that patch. Also, this was really added so that we could support batch delta ingestion (and other arbitrary InputFormats which would produce non-Text data), combiner optimization was an added benefit.

Started this after seeing javadoc of OutputSupplier that it's `scheduled for removal in June 2015`. But as @xvrl said, I've apparently overlooked hadoop compatibility issue. It would be better to postpone this for later.
@cheddar i will send two PRs one for making LookupExtractor abstract class and add bulk functions and second for the use case of unApply.
@nishantmonu51 moved out the cleaning import.
I am :+1:
@himanshug can u plus one this please
@himanshug can u please check this
:+1: after travis
bouncing for travis.
@fjy still hoping to get a little information about why the delete task was removed. Was this operation unsafe (it seems benign) or unnecessary? I wasn't able to find a specific PR in the change log.
